\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship is the fastest way to add AI to your software.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Think of Steamship as both a package manager and package hosting for AI.
Each \sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/packages}{Steamship package} runs in the cloud on a managed stack.


\chapter{Steamship in 30 seconds}
\label{\detokenize{index:steamship-in-30-seconds}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{agents/index:building-agents}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Build Agents}}}} which run in the cloud.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/index:using-plugins}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Use Plugins}}}} for common operations like generating text with GPT, converting a CSV to text, or generating an image from text. Steamship manages asynchronicity and retries.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{data/index:data-model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Store data in Files, Blocks, and Tags}}}}. This allows you to {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/queries/index:queries}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{query}}}} or {\hyperref[\detokenize{embedding-search/index:embedding-search-index}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{search}}}} it later.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\DUrole{xref,std,std-ref}{Deploy as a Package}, creating a scalable API for your front end.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\DUrole{xref,std,std-ref}{Create as many instances of the Package} as you want, each with its own data.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The best way to start is to make a simple package:


\chapter{Start from a template}
\label{\detokenize{index:start-from-a-template}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Clone one of our starter packages (\sphinxurl{https://github.com/steamship-packages}):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
git\PYG{+w}{ }clone\PYG{+w}{ }https://github.com/steamship\PYGZhy{}packages/empty\PYGZhy{}package.git
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Create a virtual environment and install dependencies:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
python3\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}m\PYG{+w}{ }venv\PYG{+w}{ }venv
\PYG{n+nb}{source}\PYG{+w}{ }venv/bin/activate

pip\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}r\PYG{+w}{ }requirements.txt
pip\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}r\PYG{+w}{ }requirements.dev.txt
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
and start editing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{src/api.py}}.


\chapter{Start from scratch}
\label{\detokenize{index:start-from-scratch}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
First, install our SDK and CLI (ideally in a virtual environment):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
python3\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}m\PYG{+w}{ }venv\PYG{+w}{ }venv
\PYG{n+nb}{source}\PYG{+w}{ }venv/bin/activate

pip\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }steamship
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Now copy this into \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{api.py}}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{invocable} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{post}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{PackageService}

\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{MyPackage}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{PackageService}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}

    \PYG{n+nd}{@post}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{hello\PYGZus{}world}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Hello, }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{name}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/index:configuration}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship, and the packages you build with it, can be used via our HTTP API, Python Client, or CLI.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Authentication}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/authentication:authentication}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/authentication::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship uses API Keys to authenticate our CLI and client libraries.
These keys can be stored in a configuration file, in environment variables, or passed manually to our client libraries.


\subsubsection{Steamship Configuration File}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/authentication:steamship-configuration-file}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Logging in with the {\hyperref[\detokenize{configuration/cli:cli}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Steamship CLI}}}} creates a configuration file at \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.steamship.json}}.
This file contains your API Key, and our client libraries will auto\sphinxhyphen{}load information from this file when available.

\sphinxAtStartPar
It looks like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}apiKey\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}mykey\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Using Multiple Profiles}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/authentication:using-multiple-profiles}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Steamship configuration file supports multiple profiles.
To create multiple profiles, use the following structure:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}apiKey\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}mykey\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}profiles:\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}testing\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}apiKey\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}test\PYGZhy{}key\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}work\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}apiKey\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}work\PYGZhy{}key\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Use a profile from the command line by setting the  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_PROFILE}} environment variable.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{STEAMSHIP\PYGZus{}PROFILE}\PYG{o}{=}work\PYG{+w}{ }ship\PYG{+w}{ }deploy
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Use a profile from the Python Client by passing it into the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Steamship}} constructor:

\begin{sphinxuseclass}{tab-content}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{client} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{profile}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{work}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}
\begin{sphinxuseclass}{tab-content}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kd}{const}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nx}{client}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{o+ow}{new}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nx}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{profile}\PYG{o}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}work\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}

\subsubsection{Environment Variables}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/authentication:environment-variables}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_KEY}} environment variable is set,
our client libraries will prioritize it over your \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} file.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Steamship Client Libraries}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/clients:steamship-client-libraries}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/clients:clients}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/clients::doc}}

\subsubsection{Python Client}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/clients:python-client}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/clients:id1}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To install the Steamship Python Client, run:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
pip\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }steamship
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then, import and use Steamship with:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Steamship}

\PYG{n}{ai\PYGZus{}package} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{package\PYGZhy{}name}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Most of this documentation site is Python\sphinxhyphen{}centric and will assume operation via that client.


\subsubsection{Typescript Client}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/clients:typescript-client}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/clients:id2}}
\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Typescript client is alpha quality.
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To install the Steamship Typescript Client, run:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
npm\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}save\PYG{+w}{ }@steamship/client
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then, import and use Steamship with:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{Workspace}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{@steamship/client}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}

\PYG{n}{const} \PYG{n}{client} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{new} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{const} \PYG{n}{instance} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{k}{await} \PYG{n}{client}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{package}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Most of this documentation site is Python\sphinxhyphen{}centric and will assume operation via that client.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Steamship CLI}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/cli:steamship-cli}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/cli:cli}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/cli::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To install the Steamship SDK and CLI, run (preferably in a virtual environment):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
pip\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }steamship
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will provide access to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ship}} command in your shell. It can be used for login and deployment

\sphinxAtStartPar
Try it out by typing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ship login}} or see options with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ship \sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}help}}.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{HTTP Operation}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/http:http-operation}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/http:http}}\label{\detokenize{configuration/http::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Our client library is designed to broker all communication to Steamship,
but our API supports HTTP operation if desired.


\subsubsection{Requests}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/http:requests}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
In general, most API requests consist of an HTTP \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{POST}} with a JSON payload.
For such requests, make sure to set the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Content\sphinxhyphen{}Type}} header as follows:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Content\PYGZhy{}Type:\PYG{+w}{ }application/json
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Also include your API Key as a Bearer token in the header:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Authorization:\PYG{+w}{ }Bearer\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}your\PYGZhy{}token\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{Optional Headers}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/http:optional-headers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
All API requests take place within the context of a {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/workspaces:workspaces}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Workspace}}}}.
If you do not specify the workspace, you are using your \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{default}} workspace.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To set the workspace in an API request, use the following header:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
X\PYGZhy{}Workspace\PYGZhy{}Handle:\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}your\PYGZhy{}workspace\PYGZhy{}handle\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\paragraph{Engine Response Format}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/http:engine-response-format}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
All Steamship Engine API responses use the following JSON format over the wire.
Each field is optional.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZob{}
  \PYGZdq{}data\PYGZdq{}:any,
  \PYGZdq{}task\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZob{}
    \PYGZdq{}taskId\PYGZdq{}:string,
    \PYGZdq{}taskState\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZdq{}creating\PYGZdq{} | \PYGZdq{}waiting\PYGZdq{} | \PYGZdq{}running\PYGZdq{} | \PYGZdq{}succeeded\PYGZdq{} | \PYGZdq{}failed\PYGZdq{},
    \PYGZdq{}taskMessage\PYGZdq{}: string,
    \PYGZdq{}taskCreatedOn\PYGZdq{}: string,
    \PYGZdq{}taskLastModifiedOn\PYGZdq{}:string
  \PYGZcb{}
\PYGZcb{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In this response structure:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{data}} contains the operation results, if available

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{task}} contains the operation progress, if it is still underway or if it has failed.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Creating a Package Instance}
\label{\detokenize{configuration/http:creating-a-package-instance}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship packages are listed in our \sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/packages}{package directory}.
To create one, sent an HTTP post with the following information:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{POST} \PYG{n}{https}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{api}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{steamship}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{api}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{v1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{package}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{instance}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{create}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{packageHandle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{the\PYGZhy{}package\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{your\PYGZhy{}new\PYGZhy{}instance\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{packageVersionHandle: }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{n}{optional}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{version}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{,}
  \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{fetchIfExists}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{true}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{config}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
    \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{key1}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{value1}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the above POST request, the \sphinxstylestrong{packageHandle} references the package you’d like to use.
The \sphinxstylestrong{handle} creates a private stack for data and infrastructure that package depends on.

\subsubsection{Invoking a Package Method}

\section{Agents}
\label{\detokenize{agents/index:agents}}\label{\detokenize{agents/index:building-agents}}\label{\detokenize{agents/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship is made for building, scaling, and managing Agents in the cloud.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A full tutorial for getting started with Agents is available here:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/learn/agent-guidebook}{Agent Guidebook}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you’re new to building Agents, we highly recommend following the above tutorial.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The following are pointers to the key Agent classes for getting started:


\subsection{Agent}
\label{\detokenize{agents/index:agent}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The basic interface for Agents is:

\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.agents.schema:steamship.agents.schema.agent.Agent}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.agents.schema.agent.Agent}}}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Implementations of this class make decisions about what Action will be taken next in an Agent workflow.


\subsection{AgentContext}
\label{\detokenize{agents/index:agentcontext}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Agent Context contains data about the context in which the Agent is running, including its
ChatHistory.


\subsection{Tool}
\label{\detokenize{agents/index:tool}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Tool is something that an Agent may make use of in service of achieving its goal. To support multi\sphinxhyphen{}modal data,
Tools in Steamship take an AgentContext as input and produce {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}} as output.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Many tools are available pre\sphinxhyphen{}packaged within the SDK:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.agents.tools.search:steamship.agents.tools.search.search.SearchTool}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.agents.tools.search.search.SearchTool}}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.agents.tools.speech_generation:steamship.agents.tools.speech_generation.generate_speech.GenerateSpeechTool}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.agents.tools.speech\_generation.generate\_speech.GenerateSpeechTool}}}}} (via ElevenLabs)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.agents.tools.image_generation:steamship.agents.tools.image_generation.dalle.DalleTool}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.agents.tools.image\_generation.dalle.DalleTool}}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.agents.tools.image_generation:steamship.agents.tools.image_generation.stable_diffusion.StableDiffusionTool}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.agents.tools.image\_generation.stable\_diffusion.StableDiffusionTool}}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
… and more in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.agents.tools}} package.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{AgentService}
\label{\detokenize{agents/index:agentservice}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.agents.service:steamship.agents.service.agent_service.AgentService}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.agents.service.agent\_service.AgentService}}}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The AgentService class provides a convenient way to deploy an Agent as a Steamship {\hyperref[\detokenize{packages/index:packages}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Package}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
All  {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.agents.service:steamship.agents.service.agent_service.AgentService}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.agents.service.agent\_service.AgentService}}}}} instances contain a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{prompt(self, prompt: str, **kwargs) \sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} List{[}Block{]}}} method from thier base class.
This method is the core \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{chat}} loop: it accepts an inbound \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{str}} in the form of a user message, and it produces a list of multimodal \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} objects that contain the response.

\sphinxstepscope


\section{Packages}
\label{\detokenize{packages/index:packages}}\label{\detokenize{packages/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{packages/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/packages}{Steamship Packages} are cloud\sphinxhyphen{}hosted software libraries you can use in any programming environment.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Think of them as regular software libraries with an upgrade:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Packages bundle a full\sphinxhyphen{}lifecycle AI stack.}
Everything necessary to go from demo to production in minutes: code, models, data, and infrastructure.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Packages auto\sphinxhyphen{}manage their own infrastructure.}
If a package depends on an embedding index or a fine\sphinxhyphen{}tuned model, you don’t have to care.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Packages are stateful.}
You can create as many instances as you want: one per user, one per chat room, one per document folder. They remember their context.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
That gives you the ability to use the full breadth of modern AI with a single \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{import}} statement.

\section{Plugins}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/index:plugins}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/plugins}{Steamship Plugins} perform specific tasks related to AI.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
How to {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/index:using-plugins}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{use plugins}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
How to {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/developing/index:developingpluginssec}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{develop plugins}}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship supports the following types of plugins:


\subsection{File Importers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/index:file-importers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Importers pull raw data from common external sources into a {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{File}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Examples}: A YouTube video importer imports video content given a URL, A Notion importer imports a document from a Notion space.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/importers/index:file-importers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Using File Importers}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/developing/importers:developingfileimporters}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Developing File Importers}}}}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Blockifiers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/index:blockifiers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Blockifiers extract text and other content from raw data in a {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{File}}}} to {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Examples}: Whisper speech to text turns an audio file into a text transcript, a PDF extractor could pull the text chunks and images from a PDF document.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:blockifiers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Using Importers}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/developing/blockifiers:developingblockifierssec}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Developing Importers}}}}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Taggers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/index:taggers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Taggers create {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/tags:tags}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tags}}}} (annotations) on {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Files}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Examples}: A text classifier would attach a classification \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tag}} to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}}, an image object recognizer would add \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tags}} to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} that identified known objects.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index:taggers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Using Taggers}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/developing/taggers:developingtaggers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Developing Taggers}}}}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Generators}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/index:generators}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Generators create new content from existing content.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Examples}: GPT4 creates more text based on the existing text in a conversation, DALL\sphinxhyphen{}E creates an image based on a description.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:generators}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Using Generators}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/developing/generators:developinggenerators}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Developing Taggers}}}}

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Embedders}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/index:embedders}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Embedders convert content into a vector representation. This is primarily used in combination with Steamship’s built in :ref:\textless{}Embedding Search Index\textgreater{}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Examples}: Use OpenAI to embed sentences into vectors for search; embed images into vectors for search
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/embedders/index:embedders}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Using Embedders}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/developing/embedders:developingembedders}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Developing Embedders}}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstepscope


\subsubsection{Using Plugins}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/index:using-plugins}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/plugins}{Steamship Plugins} perform specific tasks related to AI.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This page is about using existing plugins. If you want to develop a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Plugin}}, see {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/developing/index:developingpluginssec}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Developing Plugins}}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship supports the following types of plugins:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/importers/index:file-importers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{File Importers}}}} pull raw data from common external sources into {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Files}}}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:blockifiers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blockifiers}}}} extract text and other content from raw data from {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Files}}}} to {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index:taggers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Taggers}}}} create {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/tags:tags}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tags}}}} (annotations) on {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Files}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:generators}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Generators}}}} create new {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}} (content) from existing {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}} (content).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/embedders/index:embedders}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Embedders}}}} convert content into a vector representation. This is primarily used in combination with Steamship’s built in Embedding Search.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Plugin Instances}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/index:plugin-instances}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/index:creating-plugin-instances}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To use a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Plugin}}, create an instance of it. When building into a {\hyperref[\detokenize{packages/index:packages}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Package}}}}, We recommend doing this in the constructor, and saving the result as a member
variable.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{gpt4} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{steamship}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{gpt\PYGZhy{}4}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{gpt4}} is now a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PluginInstance}}. The instance contains the plugin’s configuration and is locked to the current version of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Plugin}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To use a specific version of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Plugin}}, pass the version handle:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{gpt4} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{steamship}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{gpt\PYGZhy{}4}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{version}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{0.0.1\PYGZhy{}rc.4}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To override default configuration parameters or provide required configuration values, pass a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dict}} of values in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{config}} parameter:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{gpt4} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{steamship}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{gpt\PYGZhy{}4}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{config}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{max\PYGZus{}tokens}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1024}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To see available configuration parameters, check the documentation of the specific \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Plugin}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To use a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PluginInstance}}, call the type\sphinxhyphen{}specific methods on it:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{result\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{gpt4}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{What}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{s up GPT?}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Plugin invocations return asynchronous {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/tasks:tasks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tasks}}}} so that you can easily run many plugins and control when you need
the results.

\sphinxAtStartPar
See the plugin individual plugin types for further info on how each can be called.


\subparagraph{Plugin FAQ}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/index:plugin-faq}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/index:can-i-access-my-plugin-over-http}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Can I access my plugin over HTTP?}}}}

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Can I access my plugin over HTTP?}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/index:can-i-access-my-plugin-over-http}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/index:id2}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Yes. While the preferred access pattern for plugins is via our SDK, Steamship does expose an HTTP API endpoint for plugin instance invocation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The HTTP endpoint for plugin instance invocation is: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{https://api.steamship.com/api/v1/plugin/instance/\{plugin\sphinxhyphen{}method\}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Replace \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{plugin\sphinxhyphen{}method\}}} with the name of the method you wish to invoke on your instance. For instance, for {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:generators}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Generators}}}}, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{generate}} and
for {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index:taggers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Taggers}}}}, use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tag}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Your HTTP call MUST use the following conventions:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Set the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Content\sphinxhyphen{}Type}} header to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{application/json}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Set the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Authorization}} header to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Bearer \{api\sphinxhyphen{}key\}}}, replacing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\{api\sphinxhyphen{}key\}}} with your API Key

\item {} \begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Set one of the following headers:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{X\sphinxhyphen{}Workspace\sphinxhyphen{}Id}} (to the workspace UUID for your workspace)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{X\sphinxhyphen{}Workspace\sphinxhyphen{}Handle}} (to the workspace handle for your workspace)

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Default to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{HTTP POST}} if you’re not sure which verb to use. The plugin documentation should specify.

\item {} \begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Add the arguments as a JSON\sphinxhyphen{}encoded POST Body}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This MUST include a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pluginInstance}} field set to the instance handle of your plugin.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For example, the HTTP equivalent of:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{gpt4}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Name three kinds of dogs}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
would be:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{POST} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{api}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{v1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{plugin}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{instance}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{generate}
\PYG{n}{Content}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{application}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{json}
\PYG{n}{Authorization}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Bearer} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{api}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{key}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{n}{X}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Workspace}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Id}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{workspace}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{id}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{appendOutputToFile}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{false}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{text}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Name three kinds of dogs}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{pluginInstance}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{plugin\PYGZhy{}instance\PYGZhy{}handle\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The HTTP call to a plugin will return JSON that includes a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{taskId}}. For example:
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{     }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}status\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}version\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}1\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}userId\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZlt{}redacted\PYGZgt{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}input\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZob{}\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}appendOutputToFile\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}: false, \PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}text\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}Name three kinds of dogs\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}, \PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}pluginInstance\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZlt{}redacted\PYGZgt{}\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZcb{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}taskType\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}internalApi\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}taskId\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}48025A24...F1CF\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}workspaceId\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZlt{}redacted\PYGZgt{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}taskCreatedOn\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}2023\PYGZhy{}06\PYGZhy{}28T03:57:41Z\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZbs{}/api\PYGZbs{}/v1\PYGZbs{}/plugin\PYGZbs{}/instance\PYGZbs{}/generate\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}state\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}waiting\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{         }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}taskLastModifiedOn\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}2023\PYGZhy{}06\PYGZhy{}28T03:57:41Z\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{+w}{     }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To retrieve the output, you can poll the Task via HTTP, using the Task status endpoint (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{https://api.steamship.com/api/v1/task/status}}):
\begin{quote}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{POST} \PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{api}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{v1}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{status}
\PYG{n}{Content}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Type}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{application}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{json}
\PYG{n}{Authorization}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Bearer} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{api}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{key}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{n}{X}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Workspace}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{Id}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{workspace}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n+nb}{id}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}

\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{taskId}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{task\PYGZhy{}id\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}
\end{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If the task has completed successfully, you will see something like:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}data\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{        }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}blocks\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{[\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{            }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}tags\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{[\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{                }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}kind\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}role\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{                }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}name\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}assistant\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{+w}{            }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}],}
\PYG{+w}{            }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}text\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}1. Labrador Retriever\PYGZbs{}n2. German Shepherd\PYGZbs{}n3. Beagle\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{+w}{        }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}]}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{},}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}status\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{        }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}input\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZob{}\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}appendOutputToFile\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}: false, \PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}text\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}Name three kinds of dogs\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}, \PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}pluginInstance\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}: \PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZlt{}redacted\PYGZgt{}\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZcb{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{        }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}userId\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZlt{}redacted\PYGZgt{}\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{        }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}taskLastModifiedOn\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}2023\PYGZhy{}06\PYGZhy{}28T03:57:42Z\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{        }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}taskType\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}internalApi\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}

\PYG{+w}{        }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}taskId\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}48025A24...F1CF\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}

\subparagraph{File Importers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/importers/index:file-importers}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/importers/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/importers/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
File Importers import raw, unprocessed data into Steamship.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A File Importer’s input is a URL or raw bytes.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A File Importer’s output is raw bytes plus a MIME type.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can use File Importers when developing Steamship packages, in your own Python app code, or as one\sphinxhyphen{}off functions that
import data in the cloud.


\subparagraph{Using File Importers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/importers/index:using-file-importers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To use a {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/importers/index:file-importers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{file importer}}}}, create an instance within your workspace and then refer to it when creating a file.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Load a Steamship Worksapce}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{File}
\PYG{n}{client} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{workspace}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my\PYGZhy{}workspace\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Upload a file}
\PYG{n}{importer} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{client}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{file\PYGZhy{}importer\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{instance\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{config}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create a file via that plugin instance.}
\PYG{n}{file} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{File}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create\PYGZus{}with\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{client}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{plugin\PYGZus{}instance}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{importer}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{handle}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The documentation for the file importer you use will provide instructions about how to pass required arguments to it.
Some require configuration (provided at plugin instance creation time) and others require a URL (provided at file creation time).

\sphinxstepscope


\subparagraph{Blockifiers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:blockifiers}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Blockifiers convert data into Steamship’s native {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/index:data-model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Block format}}}}.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{A Blockifier’s input} is raw bytes. Examples include a PDF, image,
audio, HTML, CSV, JSON\sphinxhyphen{}formatted API output, or so on.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{A Blockifier’s output} is an object in {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/index:data-model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Steamship Block format}}}}.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
All data imported into Steamship must be first blockified before it can be used.

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can use blockifiers when developing Steamship {\hyperref[\detokenize{packages/index:packages}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Packages}}}}, in your own Python app code,
or as one\sphinxhyphen{}off functions that convert data in the cloud.


\subparagraph{Using Blockifiers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:using-blockifiers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To use a blockifier, create an instance with your Steamship client and apply it to a file.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Load a Steamship Workspace}
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{File}
\PYG{n}{client} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{workspace}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my\PYGZhy{}workspace\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Upload a file}
\PYG{n}{file} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{File}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{path}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{path/to/some\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create the blockifier instance}
\PYG{n}{blockifier} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{client}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{blockifier\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{instance\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Apply the blockifier to the file}
\PYG{n}{task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blockify}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{blockifier}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{handle}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Wait until the blockify task completes remotely}
\PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Refresh the file to see the output}
\PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{refresh}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} file.blocks now has the blockified content}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the above code, the two key lines are:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{blockifier} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{client}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{blockifier\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blockify}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{blockifier}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{handle}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In these lines, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{blockifier\sphinxhyphen{}handle}} identifies which blockifier you would like to use, and
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{instance\sphinxhyphen{}handle}} identifies your particular instance of this blockifier in a workspace.
The same instance is reused, rather than created, if you load it like this again.


\subparagraph{Common Blockifiers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:common-blockifiers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship maintains a growing collection of official blockifiers for common scenarios.
Our goal is to always map our defaults to best of breed models so that you can get work done quickly without worrying
about the details of model selection and tuning.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Our currently supported blockifiers are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/plugins/markdown-blockifier-default}{markdown\sphinxhyphen{}default} \sphinxhyphen{} Converts Markdown to Steamship Blocks

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/plugins/s2t-blockifier-default}{speech\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}text\sphinxhyphen{}default} \sphinxhyphen{} Converts audio to Steamship Blocks

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/plugins/whisper-s2t-blockifier}{whisper\sphinxhyphen{}s2t\sphinxhyphen{}blockifier} \sphinxhyphen{} Converts audio to Steamship Blocks (via \sphinxhref{https://openai.com/blog/whisper/}{Whisper})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/plugins/wikipedia-blockifier}{wikipedia\sphinxhyphen{}blockifier} \sphinxhyphen{} Converts Wikipedia pages to Steamship Blocks

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/plugins/csv-blockifier}{csv\sphinxhyphen{}blockifier} \sphinxhyphen{} Converts CSV to Steamship Blocks

\end{itemize}


\subparagraph{Input}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:input}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The input to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{blockify}} operation is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}} with no \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}}.


\subparagraph{Output}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:output}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
When you call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{blockify}} on a file, the object that is returned is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}}. You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{wait()}} on
this task, or continue on to do other work.
The output of a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{blockify}} operation is {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}} and potentially {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/tags:tags}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tags}}}} on that file. However, since the operation happens asynchronously on the back\sphinxhyphen{}end, you will
need to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{refresh()}} the file to see the output.

\sphinxstepscope


\subparagraph{Taggers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index:taggers}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Taggers add {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/tags:tags}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tags}}}} (annotations) to {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}} (content). These tags can be {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/queries/index:queries}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{queried}}}} and composed later.


\subparagraph{Using Taggers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index:using-taggers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To use a tagger, create an instance within your workspace and then apply it to a file.
Note that a file must first have {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}}, either by direct creation or using a {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:blockifiers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blockifier}}}}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{File}
\PYG{n}{client} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{workspace}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my\PYGZhy{}workspace\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{file} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{File}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{client}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{blocks}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{Block}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{some text to tag}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create the tagger instance}
\PYG{n}{tagger} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{client}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{tagger\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Apply the tagger to the file}
\PYG{n}{tagger\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{tag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{tagger}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{handle}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{tagger\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Refresh the file to see new tags}
\PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{refresh}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} and/or Query across the persisted tags returned from tagging.}
\PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{query}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{blocktag AND name }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{paragraph}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subparagraph{Input}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index:input}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The input to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tag}} operation is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}}.  Most \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Taggers}} by default will tag all \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}} within that file.


\subparagraph{Output}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index:output}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
When you call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tag}} on a file or via a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PluginInstance}}, the object that is returned is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}}. You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{wait()}} on
this task, or continue on to do other work.
The output to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tag}} operation is more {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/tags:tags}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tags}}}} on that file. However, since the tag operations happens asynchronously on the back\sphinxhyphen{}end, you will
need to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{refresh()}} the file to see the output:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{tagger\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{tag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{tagger}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{handle}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{tagger\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Refresh the file to see new tags}
\PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{refresh}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstepscope


\subparagraph{Generators}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:generators}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Generators create more {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}} (content) on a {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{File}}}}.


\subparagraph{Using Generators}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:using-generators}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To use a generator, create an instance within your workspace and then invoke it.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{File}
\PYG{n}{client} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{workspace}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my\PYGZhy{}workspace\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create the generator instance}
\PYG{n}{generator} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{client}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{generator\PYGZhy{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Apply the generator to some text}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{some text}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{blocks} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{output}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blocks}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subparagraph{Input}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:input}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
There are several ways to specify input to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Generator}}:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Raw Text} You can pass raw text directly to a generator:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{some text}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Blocks of an existing File} You can pass the generator a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}} id to work on, optionally passing a subset of blocks:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Pass all the Blocks in the File}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{id}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Pass some of the Blocks in the File}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} in this example the second and third blocks (zero\PYGZhy{}indexed)}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{id}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}start\PYGZus{}block\PYGZus{}index}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}end\PYGZus{}block\PYGZus{}index}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Pass in specific blocks from the file}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} in this example the third and fifth (zero\PYGZhy{}indexed)}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{id}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}block\PYGZus{}index\PYGZus{}list}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{A query for existing Blocks} You can pass the generator a {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/queries/index:queries}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{query}}}} that will produce \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}} for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Generator}}.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Pass all the Blocks in the File}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{block\PYGZus{}query}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{kind }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{some\PYGZhy{}relevant\PYGZhy{}tag\PYGZhy{}kind}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Public output} If you wish to make the output of the generation public (for example an image or audio file), you can pass \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{make\_output\_public = True}} to the call to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{generate}}.


\subparagraph{Output}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:output}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
When you call \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{generate}} on a file or via a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PluginInstance}}, the object that is returned is a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}}. You can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{wait()}} on
this task, or continue on to do other work.
The output to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{generate}} operation is {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}}. You can always get these blocks from the output of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Apply the generator to some text}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{some text}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{blocks} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{output}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blocks}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
By default, this output is \sphinxstylestrong{not} saved to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}}.  If you wish the result to be persisted,
you can pass \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{append\_output\_to\_file=True}} to the call, and it will be persisted to a \sphinxstylestrong{new} \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Apply the generator to some text}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{some text}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{append\PYGZus{}output\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{blocks} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{output}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blocks}
\PYG{n}{new\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}id} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{blocks}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{file\PYGZus{}id}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you want the output to be appended to an existing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}}, just pass its id as well:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Apply the generator to some text}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{some text}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{append\PYGZus{}output\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{output\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{id}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{blocks} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{generator\PYGZus{}task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{output}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blocks}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} if we refresh my\PYGZus{}file, we will see new blocks}
\PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{refresh}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship provides several Generators:

\sphinxstepscope


\subparagraph{DALL\sphinxhyphen{}E}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/dalle:dall-e}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/dalle:dalle}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/dalle::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The DALL\sphinxhyphen{}E \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Generator}} plugin uses OpenAI’s DALL\sphinxhyphen{}E to generate an image from a text description.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The plugin will combine all text that is passed to it into a single prompt for image generation. The plugin
handles retrying for rate limits and uses Steamship’s OpenAI API key by default, eliminating the need
for you to have a separate OpenAI account.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The simplest possible example is:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{dalle} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{steamship}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{dall\PYGZhy{}e}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{dalle}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{A cat on a bicycle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{image\PYGZus{}content} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{output}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blocks}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{raw}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:generators}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Generator}}}} interface supports many other ways to provide input and persist output.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The DALL\sphinxhyphen{}E plugin has a few {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/index:creating-plugin-instances}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{configuration parameters}}}}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{openai\_api\_key}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{str}}, An openAI API key to use. If left default, will use Steamship’s API key.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{n}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{numeric}}, How many images to generate for each prompt.  This is how many \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}} will be in the output.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{size}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{str}}, default “1024x1024”, The size of the ouptut images.  May be "1024x1024", "512x512", or "256x256".

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{max\_retries}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{int}}, default 8, Maximum number of retries to make when generating.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{request\_timeout}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{float}}, default 600, maximum seconds to wait on calls to OpenAI.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstepscope


\subparagraph{GPT\sphinxhyphen{}4 (and GPT 3.5)}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/gpt4:gpt-4-and-gpt-3-5}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/gpt4:gpt4}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/gpt4::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The GPT\sphinxhyphen{}4 \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Generator}} plugin uses OpenAI’s GPT\sphinxhyphen{}4 to generate text from a text prompt,
or the continuation of a chat. It can also be used with GPT\sphinxhyphen{}3.5 by passing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"gpt\sphinxhyphen{}3.5\sphinxhyphen{}turbo"}}
as the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{model}} configuration parameter.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The plugin will treat each \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} of the input as an element of a chat. If a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} has
a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tag}} of kind “role” and name ( “system” | “user” | “assistant” ), the content will be passed
to OpenAI with the corresponding role. If a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} does not have a role tag, it will
be passed with the configured default role, which defaults to “user” (see config params below).

\sphinxAtStartPar
The plugin handles retrying for rate limits and uses Steamship’s OpenAI API key by default,
eliminating the need for you to have a separate OpenAI account.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The simplest possible example is:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{gpt4} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{steamship}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{gpt\PYGZhy{}4}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{gpt4}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Tell me a joke}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{joke} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{output}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blocks}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{text}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To build a chat interaction, you can persist the prompt components to a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}} object,
tagging them with their conversational roles:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{gpt4} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{steamship}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{gpt\PYGZhy{}4}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{chat\PYGZus{}file} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{File}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{client}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{blocks}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}
    \PYG{n}{Block}\PYG{p}{(}
        \PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{You are an assistant who likes to tell jokes about bananas}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
        \PYG{n}{tags}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{Tag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ROLE}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{RoleTag}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{SYSTEM}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}
    \PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{chat\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append\PYGZus{}block}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Do you know any fruit jokes?}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{tags}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{Tag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ROLE}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{RoleTag}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{USER}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{task} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{gpt4}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{generate}\PYG{p}{(}
    \PYG{n}{input\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{chat\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{id}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{append\PYGZus{}output\PYGZus{}to\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{,}
    \PYG{n}{output\PYGZus{}file\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{chat\PYGZus{}file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{id}
\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{wait}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{joke} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{task}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{output}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{blocks}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{text}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the example above, in addition to being returned as the result of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}}, the output
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} is appended to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{chat\_file}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
All output \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}} will be tagged with the “assistant” role to allow more
content to be easily appended and generated.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:generators}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Generator}}}} interface supports many other ways to provide input and persist output.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The GPT\sphinxhyphen{}4 plugin has a few {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/index:creating-plugin-instances}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{configuration parameters}}}}:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{openai\_api\_key}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{str}}, An openAI API key to use. If left default, will use Steamship’s API key.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{max\_tokens}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{int}}, default 256, The maximum number of tokens to generate per request. Can be overridden in runtime options.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{model}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{str}} , default “gpt\sphinxhyphen{}4”, The OpenAI model to use. Can be a pre\sphinxhyphen{}existing fine\sphinxhyphen{}tuned model.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{temperature}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{float}} , default 0.4, Controls randomness. Lower values produce higher likelihood / more predictable results; higher values produce more variety. Values between 0\sphinxhyphen{}1.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{top\_p}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{int}}, default 1, Controls the nucleus sampling, where the model considers the results of the tokens with top\_p probability mass. Values between 0\sphinxhyphen{}1.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{presence\_penalty}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{int}}, default 0, Control how likely the model will reuse words. Positive values penalize new tokens based on whether they appear in the text so far, increasing the model’s likelihood to talk about new topics. Number between \sphinxhyphen{}2.0 and 2.0.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{frequency\_penalty}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{int}}, default 0, Control how likely the model will reuse words. Positive values penalize new tokens based on their existing frequency in the text so far, decreasing the model’s likelihood to repeat the same line verbatim. Number between \sphinxhyphen{}2.0 and 2.0.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{moderate\_output}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bool}} , default True, Pass the generated output back through OpenAI’s moderation endpoint and throw an exception if flagged.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{max\_retries}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{int}} , default 8, Maximum number of retries to make when generating.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{request\_timeout}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{float}}, default 600, Timeout for requests to OpenAI completion API. Default is 600 seconds.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{n}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{int}}, default 1, How many completions to generate for each prompt.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{default\_role}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{str}}, default RoleTag.USER, The default role to use for a block that does not have a Tag of kind=’role’

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{default\_system\_prompt}}: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{str}} , default “”, System prompt that will be prepended before every request

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Additionally, stopwords can be passed in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{stop}} parameter in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{options}} of the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{generate}} call. Other parameters may be overridden on an individual invocation by passing
them in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{options}} as well.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Other generators are available on the Steamship \sphinxhref{https://www.steamship.com/plugins?tab=Public}{plugins page}

\sphinxstepscope


\subparagraph{Embedders}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/embedders/index:embedders}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/embedders/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/embedders/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Embedders are a special case of Taggers which convert data into vector format.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The main reason to use an embedder is to provide data to an {\hyperref[\detokenize{embedding-search/index:embedding-search-index}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Embedding Search Index for search}}}}.

\sphinxstepscope


\subparagraph{Tasks}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/tasks:tasks}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/tasks:id1}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/tasks::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Most {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/index:plugins}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Plugin}}}} operations return a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}}.  This allows you to conveniently handle the long,
asynchronous aspect of many plugin invocations.


\subparagraph{Waiting on Tasks}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/tasks:waiting-on-tasks}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If your code does not need to do any other work while the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Plugin}} is running, you may \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{wait()}} on the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}}:

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will make your code poll the Steamship service until either the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}} is complete, or the wait timeout is reached.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Waiting on the task may time out before the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}} is complete. Don’t worry, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}} is still running on the server.
You can increase the time you wait by passing the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{max\_timeout\_s}} parameter.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subparagraph{Returning Tasks from a Package}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/using/tasks:returning-tasks-from-a-package}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
One common pattern when your package does long asynchronous work is to return a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}} id which can
be used later to check on the status of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}}. To check the status of a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}} from its id:

\sphinxAtStartPar
Once you have a task object again, you can \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{wait()}} on it, or check its \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{state}} variable.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsubsection{Developing Plugins}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/index:developing-plugins}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/index:developingpluginssec}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Each plugin is a stateless, Python\sphinxhyphen{}based microservice that runs in the
cloud and conforms to a strict interface and data model. Plugins may do
work themselves, or they may adapt work done by third\sphinxhyphen{}party services for
use with Steamship.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To implement a plugin, you simply fill in the required abstract methods from the appropriate \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PluginService}} abstract class.
If you’ve implemented the required abstract methods, you have successfully built a plugin!

\sphinxAtStartPar
Read more here:

\sphinxstepscope


\paragraph{Plugin Project Structure}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/project-structure:plugin-project-structure}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/project-structure::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Your main implementation lives in the  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{src/api.py}} file of your project.
This file will have been created for you by the template you selected when starting your project.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Inside this file, you will find a class that derives from a base class specific to the plugin type.

\sphinxAtStartPar
From the implementation perspective, think of a plugin as a class that implements an Abstract Base Class that the Steamship Engine knows how to communicate with.
Each plugin type implements an abstract base class with a different contract.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Consider the following tagger plugin:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{TagFileTagger}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Tagger}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
 \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{PluginRequest}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{BlockAndTagPluginInput}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{BlockAndTagPluginOutput}\PYG{p}{:}
     \PYG{n}{file} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{file}
     \PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{tags}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{append}\PYG{p}{(}
       \PYG{n}{Tag}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{CreateRequest}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Demo}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{You}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{ve been tagged!}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
     \PYG{p}{)}
     \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{BlockAndTagPluginOutput}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{file}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Once deployed to Steamship, this plugin can be applied to files in Steamship, leaving each one with a tag that can be
queried later.

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can also {\hyperref[\detokenize{developing/configuration:id1}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{define configuration parameters}}}} for your plugin.

\sphinxstepscope
