\paragraph{Developing Blockifiers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/blockifiers:developing-blockifiers}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/blockifiers:developingblockifierssec}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/blockifiers::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To develop a blockifier, first follow the instructions in {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/developing/index:developingpluginssec}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Developing Plugins}}}} to create
a new plugin project. This will result in a full, working plugin scaffold that you could
deploy and use immediately.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then, read below details about how to modify that scaffold for your own needs.


\subparagraph{The Blockifier Contract}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/blockifiers:the-blockifier-contract}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Blockifiers are responsible for transforming raw data into Steamship Block Format.
Using our SDK, that means implementing the following method:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{MyBlockifier}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Blockifier}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{run}\PYG{p}{(}
       \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{PluginRequest}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{RawDataPluginInput}\PYG{p}{]}
    \PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{Union}\PYG{p}{[}
       \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{,}
       \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{BlockAndTagPluginOutput}\PYG{p}{]}
    \PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{pass}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subparagraph{How to Structure Blocks and Tags}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/blockifiers:how-to-structure-blocks-and-tags}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The biggest design question you will face when implementing a blockifier is how to structure your blocks and tags.

\sphinxAtStartPar
At the platform level, we leave this open\sphinxhyphen{}ended on purpose, but we do encourage a few conventions of common convergence.

\sphinxAtStartPar
See the {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/index:data-model}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Data Model}}}} section for a discussion of how to think effectively about blocks and tags.


\subparagraph{Synchronous Example: A Pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}Markdown Blockifier}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/blockifiers:synchronous-example-a-pseudo-markdown-blockifier}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A trivial implementation of this contract would be a pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}Markdown blockifier.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Let’s say this blockifier assumes the input data is UTF\sphinxhyphen{}8, assumes that empty new lines represent paragraph breaks.
You could implement such a blockifier with this following code:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{PretendMarkdownBlockifier}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Blockifier}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{PluginRequest}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{RawDataPluginInput}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{Union}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{PluginRequest}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{BlockAndTagPluginOutput}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{BlockAndTagPluginOutput}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Grab the raw bytes.}
        \PYG{n}{text} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}

        \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Decode it as UTF\PYGZhy{}8}
        \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n+nb}{isinstance}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n+nb}{bytes}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
            \PYG{n}{text} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{decode}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{utf\PYGZhy{}8}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

       \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Split it into paragraphs based on a double newline}
       \PYG{n}{paragraphs} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{split}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}n}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

       \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create a block for each paragraph and add a tag marking it as a paragraph}
       \PYG{n}{blocks} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{[}
         \PYG{n}{Block}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{CreateRequest}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{paragraph}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{tags}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}
             \PYG{n}{Tag}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{CreateRequest}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my\PYGZhy{}plugin}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{paragraph}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
         \PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{for} \PYG{n}{paragraph} \PYG{o+ow}{in} \PYG{n}{paragraphs}
       \PYG{p}{]}

       \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Return a BlockAndTagPluginOutput object}
       \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{BlockAndTagPluginOutput}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{file}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{File}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{CreateRequest}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{blocks}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{blocks}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
From the standpoint of the Steamship Engine, this \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PretendMarkdownBlockifier}} now provides a way to
transform any bytes claiming to be of this pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}markdown type into Steamship Block Format.


\subparagraph{Asynchronous Blockifiers}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/blockifiers:asynchronous-blockifiers}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Some blockifiers will need to call third\sphinxhyphen{}party APIs that are asynchronous.
Image\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}text (OCR) and speech\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}text (S2T) are two common examples.
When this occurs, you should make your blockifier asynchronous as well.

\sphinxAtStartPar
See the {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/developing/async-plugins:developingasync}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Developing Asynchronous Plugins}}}} section for details.

\sphinxstepscope


\paragraph{Developing Generators}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/generators:developing-generators}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/generators:developinggenerators}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/generators::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Generator}} takes {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}} as input and creates new \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}} as output.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To implement a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Generator}}, your plugin class should inherit from {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.plugin:steamship.plugin.generator.Generator}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.plugin.generator.Generator}}}}}
and implement the abstract \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{run}} method:

\sphinxAtStartPar
For example, an image \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Generator}} could merge the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{text}} from the input blocks and use it to generate an image \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In addition to the input blocks and instance \DUrole{xref,std,std-ref}{configuration}, Generators can also receive
arbitrary key/value runtime parameters.  These are present in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{request.data.options}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
See \sphinxhref{https://github.com/steamship-plugins/dall-e}{the DALL\sphinxhyphen{}E plugin} for a working example of a text to image \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Generator}}.

\sphinxstepscope

We’re excited for you to do this, but we haven’t documented it yet!

\sphinxhref{http://steamship.com/discord}{Come chat with us on Discord}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Unlike packages, plugins also offer support for asynchronous work.
This is useful when writing a plugin that, itself, contacts an asynchronous third\sphinxhyphen{}party API.
You can find the documentation for that here:

\sphinxstepscope


\paragraph{Writing Asynchronous Plugins}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/async-plugins:writing-asynchronous-plugins}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/async-plugins:developingasync}}\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/async-plugins::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If a plugin method calls a third\sphinxhyphen{}party API that is asynchronous, then that plugin should
adopt an asynchronous conversation with the Steamship Engine.
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Request{[}InputType{]}}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Response{[}OutputType{]}}} objects passed into and returned from plugin invocations contain
fields that make such an asynchronous conversation quick and easy.


\subparagraph{Signaling an Asynchronous Response}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/async-plugins:signaling-an-asynchronous-response}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A synchronous plugin method response always returns either a raw object or a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Response}} object
wrapping a raw object:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{SomePlugin}\PYG{p}{:}
   \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
      \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{some\PYGZus{}object}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
To make this response asynchronous, return a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Response}} object with the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{status}} field set to a
running \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}} object:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{SomePlugin}\PYG{p}{:}
   \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{run}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
      \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{(}
          \PYG{n}{status}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{Task}\PYG{p}{(}
             \PYG{n}{state}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TaskState}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{running}\PYG{p}{,}
             \PYG{n}{remote\PYGZus{}status\PYGZus{}input}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
          \PYG{p}{)}
      \PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
That will cause the Steamship Engine to record the plugin’s work as still \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RUNNING}}. It will schedule repeated
inquiries \textendash{} at increasingly longer intervals \textendash{} to check on whether the plugin invocation has.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{remote\_status\_input}} object on the returned \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}} contains a Python \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{dict}} that will be provided to the
plugin when this future check occurs.
It is the appropriate location to stash metadata about the async work in progress, such as a task ID received from a third\sphinxhyphen{}party API.


\subparagraph{Detecting an Asynchronous Progress Request}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/async-plugins:detecting-an-asynchronous-progress-request}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
When a plugin responds with an asyncronous task, the Engine will begin checking back for status updates.
The Engine performs these checks via the same endpoints used to initiate the work.
It is therefore important for asynchronous plugins to be able to distinguish between invocations requesting new work and invocations checking on existing work.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Request}} object contains a boolean field named \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{is\_status\_check}} that distinguishes async status requests from new work requests.
If this field is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{true}}, the request is checking the status of prior work.
If this field is \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{false}}, the request is initiating new work.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In a fully synchronous plugin method, it is generally safe to ignore the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{is\_status\_check}} field,
but if a plugin method is asynchronous, you must take care to always check it, like so:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{run}\PYG{p}{(}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{PluginRequest}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{InputType}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{Union}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OutputType}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OutputType}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}

   \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{is\PYGZus{}status\PYGZus{}check}\PYG{p}{:}
       \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{check\PYGZus{}status}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{)}
    \PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
       \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{initiate\PYGZus{}work}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the above code, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{initiate\_work}} method would return a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Task}} in the running
state with a useful \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{remote\_status\_input}} field, as follows:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{initiate\PYGZus{}work}\PYG{p}{(}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{PluginRequest}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{InputType}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{Union}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OutputType}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OutputType}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}

     \PYG{n}{remote\PYGZus{}job\PYGZus{}id} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{api\PYGZus{}client}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{do\PYGZus{}something}\PYG{p}{(}
       \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{data}
     \PYG{p}{)}

     \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{(}
         \PYG{n}{status}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{Task}\PYG{p}{(}
            \PYG{n}{state}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TaskState}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{RUNNING}\PYG{p}{,}
            \PYG{n}{remote\PYGZus{}status\PYGZus{}input}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
              \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{remote\PYGZus{}job\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{remote\PYGZus{}job\PYGZus{}id}
            \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
         \PYG{p}{)}
     \PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
And then the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{check\_status}} method would retrieve the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{remote\_status\_input}} to check
on the status of the remote work.
If the work remains in progress, it responds with a task in the running state, just as before.
If the work is complete, it responds with the raw data object or a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Response}} object wrapping it.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{check\PYGZus{}status}\PYG{p}{(}
        \PYG{n+nb+bp}{self}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{PluginRequest}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{InputType}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{Union}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{BlockAndTagPluginOutput}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OutputType}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}

     \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Fetch the key we know we set when backgrounding the task.}
     \PYG{n}{remote\PYGZus{}job\PYGZus{}id} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{request}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{remote\PYGZus{}status\PYGZus{}input}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{get}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{remote\PYGZus{}job\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

     \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{api\PYGZus{}client}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{is\PYGZus{}complete}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{remote\PYGZus{}job\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{data}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{some\PYGZus{}output\PYGZus{}object}\PYG{p}{)}
     \PYG{k}{else}\PYG{p}{:}
        \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{Response}\PYG{p}{(}
            \PYG{n}{status}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{Task}\PYG{p}{(}
               \PYG{n}{state}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TaskState}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{RUNNING}\PYG{p}{,}
               \PYG{n}{remote\PYGZus{}status\PYGZus{}input}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
                 \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{remote\PYGZus{}job\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{remote\PYGZus{}job\PYGZus{}id}
               \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
            \PYG{p}{)}
        \PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subparagraph{Throwing errors from an asynchronous plugin}
\label{\detokenize{plugins/developing/async-plugins:throwing-errors-from-an-asynchronous-plugin}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Errors can be thrown from an asynchronous plugin just as they would be from a synchronous plugin.
Just raise a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SteamshipError}} and the Engine will set the task’s state to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{TaskState.FAILED}} and record the error output.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{SteamshipError}
\PYG{k}{raise} \PYG{n}{SteamshipError}\PYG{p}{(}
   \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Some error message}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{error}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{optional\PYGZus{}wrapped\PYGZus{}error}
\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstepscope


\section{Data Model}
\label{\detokenize{data/index:data-model}}\label{\detokenize{data/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{data/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
There are only three core concepts you need to know.
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Files}}}} are the top level object for storing data. A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}} can store raw data and an ordered list of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}} are chunks of content within a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}}.  They can contain raw data and/or text, and an unordered set of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tags}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{data/tags:tags}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tags}}}} are typed annotations on a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}}.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The following diagram shows how data is created and used within Steamship:

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{file-lifecycle}.png}
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
File raw data can either be {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:creating-files-directly}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{created directly}}}} or {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/importers/index:file-importers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{imported via a File Importer}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Blocks on Files can either be {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:creating-blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{created directly}}}} or {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:blockifiers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{created from raw data by a Blockifier}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Once you have blocks, you can run {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/generators/index:generators}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Generators}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/taggers/index:taggers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Taggers}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Find data that you need by {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/queries/index:queries}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{querying}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Index data for search with {\hyperref[\detokenize{embedding-search/index:embedding-search-index}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{the embedding search index}}}}

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Workspaces}
\label{\detokenize{data/workspaces:workspaces}}\label{\detokenize{data/workspaces:id1}}\label{\detokenize{data/workspaces::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Workspaces contain all the data and Package and Plugin instances within Steamship. It is highly recommended
to create an instance of a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Package}} in a new \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Workspace}} to avoid data conflicts.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Workspaces can be used in two ways:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{As the backing store to Packages.}
Each {\hyperref[\detokenize{packages/index:packages}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Steamship Package}}}} instance is bound to a Workspace, giving it an isolated environment to store state and model parameters.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{As a cloud environment for language AI projects.}
You can use Workspaces on their own from Jupyter notebooks or your own application code.

\end{enumerate}


\subsubsection{Creating Workspaces}
\label{\detokenize{data/workspaces:creating-workspaces}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Workspaces are created (or resumed) when creating a new Steamship client.
In your client’s constructor, specify the workspace you’d like.
If it doesn’t exist, it will be created for you.

\begin{sphinxuseclass}{tab-content}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{Steamship}

\PYG{n}{client} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{workspace}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my\PYGZhy{}workspace\PYGZhy{}name}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}
\begin{sphinxuseclass}{tab-content}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{import}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nx}{Steamship}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kr}{from}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}@steamship/client\PYGZdq{}}

\PYG{k+kd}{const}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nx}{client}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nx}{Steamship}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n+nx}{workspace}\PYG{o}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}my\PYGZhy{}workspace\PYGZhy{}name\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}
\begin{sphinxuseclass}{tab-content}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
curl\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}header\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Content\PYGZhy{}Type: application/json\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}header\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Authorization: Bearer }\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}STEAMSHIP\PYGZus{}KEY}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}request\PYG{+w}{ }POST\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}data\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}\PYGZob{}\PYGZdq{}handle\PYGZdq{}:\PYGZdq{}your\PYGZhy{}handle\PYGZdq{}, \PYGZdq{}fetchIfExist\PYGZdq{}:true\PYGZcb{}\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }https://api.steamship.com/api/v1/workspace/create
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Every workspace\sphinxhyphen{}specific operation this client performs will now take part in that workspace.
This includes file uploads, plugin training, plugin inference, queries, and any infrastructure associated.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you need to switch your workspace, you can either create a new client or type:

\begin{sphinxuseclass}{tab-content}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{client}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{switch\PYGZus{}workspace}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{new\PYGZhy{}workspace\PYGZhy{}name}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}
\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Files}
\label{\detokenize{data/files:files}}\label{\detokenize{data/files:id1}}\label{\detokenize{data/files::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Files are the top\sphinxhyphen{}level object for any piece of data in a workspace.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Files hold bytes of raw data (with a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mime\_type}}, and processed data in {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}}.
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}} may also have a list of {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/tags:tags}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tags}}}} (annotations).

\sphinxAtStartPar
To do work on a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}}, it needs to be saved and its content must be in {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Blocks}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
There are a few ways to accomplish this:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Create \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} content directly (see below)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Add raw data directly, then create \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}} with a {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:blockifiers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{blockifier plugin}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Import raw data with a {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/importers/index:file-importers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{File Importer}}}}, then create \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}} with a {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/blockifiers/index:blockifiers}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{blockifier plugin}}}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
It’s useful to think of Steamship Files more broadly than “file on your desktop.”
They are any useful object:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A conversation between a user and an assistant

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
a PDF file

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
a YouTube video

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
a Podcast episode

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Notion page

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
the JSON representation of an AirTable API response

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.data:steamship.data.file.File}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File PyDoc spec here}}}}}.


\subsubsection{Creating Files Directly}
\label{\detokenize{data/files:creating-files-directly}}\label{\detokenize{data/files:id2}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The quickest way to create data is to create Files with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} content directly:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{file} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{File}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{create}\PYG{p}{(}
   \PYG{n}{client}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{client}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{blocks}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{Block}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{text}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Some example text}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Making File Data Public}
\label{\detokenize{data/files:making-file-data-public}}\label{\detokenize{data/files:public-files}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If you want the raw data bytes of a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}} to be publicly accessible, you can set the parameter \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{public\_data = True}} when calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File.create()}}.
This is useful if you wish to share a generated image or audio file, or must make the content viewable in a place that cannot
retain your Steamship API key.  You can also change the value of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{public\_data}} flag on an existing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}} by calling
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File.set\_public\_data}}.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Blocks}
\label{\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}}\label{\detokenize{data/blocks:id1}}\label{\detokenize{data/blocks::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Blocks are ordered chunks of content within a {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{File}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} may have raw data, plain text, or both.  The type of content is indicated by its \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mime\_type}}.
Blocks can store images, videos, audio clips, or any other chunk of data.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This means that different packages and plugins may choose divide files into blocks using different schemes.
Consider a CSV file uploaded to Steamship.
The following divisions of this file into blocks are all perfectly fine:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Each CSV row is a block of text.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Each 10 CSV rows is a block

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The entire CSV file is one block

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Metadata and annotations about the content of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} added via {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/tags:tags}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tags}}}} on the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} .


\subsubsection{Creating Blocks}
\label{\detokenize{data/blocks:creating-blocks}}\label{\detokenize{data/blocks:id2}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Blocks may be created when creating a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File}} by passing them in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{blocks}} parameter, or they can be appended
to an existing file.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Please see \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block.create()}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{File.append\_block()}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Read the {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.data:steamship.data.block.Block}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block PyDoc spec here}}}}}.


\subsubsection{Making Block Data Public}
\label{\detokenize{data/blocks:making-block-data-public}}\label{\detokenize{data/blocks:public-blocks}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If you want the raw data bytes of a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} to be publicly accessible, you can set the parameter \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{public\_data = True}} when calling \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block.create()}}.
This is useful if you wish to share a generated image or audio file, or must make the content viewable in a place that cannot
retain your Steamship API key.  You can also change the value of the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{public\_data}} flag on an existing \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block}} by calling
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block.set\_public\_data}}.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Tags}
\label{\detokenize{data/tags:tags}}\label{\detokenize{data/tags:id1}}\label{\detokenize{data/tags::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship uses Tags to represent all commentary about content.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The intent of a chat message

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The embedding of a sentence

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The sentiment of a phase

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The markdown semantics of a region of text

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Identified object regions of an image

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship Files and Blocks contain content. Tags hold all data \sphinxstylestrong{about} the content.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The full {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.data.tags:steamship.data.tags.tag.Tag}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tag PyDoc spec is here}}}}}, but it’s useful to look at a summarized version:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{Tag}\PYG{p}{:}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{l+s+sd}{\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}Subset of the Tag object \PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{} within the context of a Block\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}\PYGZdq{}}

  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} What the tag is}
  \PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{p}{:}  \PYG{n+nb}{str}
  \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{p}{:}  \PYG{n}{Optional}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{str}\PYG{p}{]}
  \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Optional}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{Dict}\PYG{p}{]}

  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} The span of text the tag is commenting upon.}
  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Indices are relative to the block\PYGZsq{}s text.}
  \PYG{n}{start\PYGZus{}idx}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Optional}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Start inclusive}
  \PYG{n}{end\PYGZus{}idx}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{Optional}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{]}   \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} End exclusive}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This design results in a flexible data storage scheme that can be adapted to a number of
different scenarios. We optimize our data storage so that you can query over tags and their contents.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Here are a few examples to help you think of how tags are used.

\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}
