\subsubsection{Tag Schemas}
\label{\detokenize{data/tags:tag-schemas}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship brings together many models under one roof using tags as the common representation for interoperation.
But doesn’t fully solve the model interop problem: how do we make sure all models use the same tags?

\sphinxAtStartPar
Where possible, we use a common schema for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{kind}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{name}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value}} properties of a tag.
If all sentiment models produce tags with kind \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sentiment}} and a range of names \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{{[}positive, neutral, negative{]}}}, for example, then we can swap them in and out as needed.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Our ongoing pursuit of this can be found in the \sphinxhref{https://github.com/steamship-core/python-client/blob/main/src/steamship/data/tags/tag\_constants.py}{tag\_constants.py file}
in Github.
There you will find Python Enum classes that have common tags across our plugins.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.data.tags:steamship.data.tags.tag_constants.TagKind}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{TagKind class}}}}} contains suggested values for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{kind}} field of a Tag.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{TagValue class}} contains suggested keys for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{valu}} dictionary of a Tag.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The following classes contain suggested values for the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{name}} field:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.data.tags:steamship.data.tags.tag_constants.DocTag}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DocTag}}}}} for document semantics (HTML, Markdown, OCR, etc)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EmotionTag}} for emotion tagging tag

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EntityTag}} for entity tagging tags

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.data.tags:steamship.data.tags.tag_constants.GenerationTag}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{GenerationTag}}}}} for models which generate new data from the covered span as input

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{IntentTag}} for intent classification

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SentimentTag}} for sentiment classification

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.data.tags:steamship.data.tags.tag_constants.RoleTag}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{RoleTag}}}}} for role classification

\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
These constants are not required, but using them increases the chance that what you build will
interoperate cleanly with everyone else that uses them.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Here is what some of the above tag examples would look like using these enum classes.
Notice how it is a combination of standard constant and “magic string” depending on whether a constant exists for that concept.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
An entity

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{data} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{EntityTag}
\PYG{n}{Tag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{ENTITY}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{EntityTag}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{PERSON}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{canonical}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Donald Duck}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A part of speech

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{data} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{TagKind}
\PYG{n}{Tag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{PART\PYGZus{}OF\PYGZus{}SPEECH}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{adj}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
An embedding

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{data} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{TagValue}
\PYG{n}{Tag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{EMBEDDING}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my\PYGZhy{}embedder}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{TagValue}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{VECTOR\PYGZus{}VALUE}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0} \PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A summarization

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{data} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{GenerationTag}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{TagValue}
\PYG{n}{Tag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{GENERATION}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{GenerationTag}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{SUMMARY}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n}{TagValue}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{STRING\PYGZus{}VALUE}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{... summary of the span covered by this tag ...}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A dictionary lookup

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{data} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{TagKind}
\PYG{n}{Tag}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kind}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{TagKind}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{TOKEN}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{name}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{ce\PYGZhy{}dict}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{value}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{chinese}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{你好}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{pinyin}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{nǐhǎo}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{english}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{hello}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Block and File Tags}
\label{\detokenize{data/tags:block-and-file-tags}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The above text discusses tags upon spans of text.
But Steamship actually supports two types of tags: \sphinxstylestrong{File Tags} and \sphinxstylestrong{Block Tags}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{File Tags} annotate a {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{File}}}} object itself:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
They are attached to the {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/files:files}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{File}}}} object (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{file.tags}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Their \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{block\_id}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{start\_idx}}, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{end\_idx}} are always null.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
They are referenced via the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{filetag}} keyword in our query system.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Block Tags} annotate text within a {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Block}}}} object:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
They are attached to the {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/blocks:blocks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Block}}}} object (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{block.tags}})

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Their \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{start\_idx}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{end\_idx}} fields are either both null or both non\sphinxhyphen{}null. If both are null, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tag is assumed to apply to the whole \textasciigrave{}\textasciigrave{}Block}}. They  represent offsets into the text that is spanned by that block.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
They are referenced via the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{blocktag}} keyword in our {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/queries/index:queries}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{query system}}}}.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Notes:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
It is impossible for a tag to cover text spanning multiple blocks.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Queries}
\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index:queries}}\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship contains a query language, \sphinxstylestrong{ShipQL}, designed to help you fetch Files, Blocks, and Tags.
ShipQL enables you to query the results of multiple AI models applied to the same text, to find files or sections identified by language AI features.

\sphinxAtStartPar
ShipQL currently supports only the criteria on which objects are matched (like a SQL WHERE clause).
It does not yet support projection and selection (like the SQL SELECT clause).


\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index:usage}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
File, Block, and Tag objects are all queryable via ShipQL.
Their objects in the Python Client have a static \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{query}} method which accepts a ShipQL string.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The object type returned from that query method depends upon the object you used to call it.
However the ShipQL predicates always refer to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tags}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For example: executing the query \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{name "Dave"}} on the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Block.query}} endpoint will return \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}} which have \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tags}} which have \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{name="Dave"}}.


\subsubsection{Language Description}
\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index:language-description}}

\paragraph{Unary Predicates}
\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index:unary-predicates}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
These predicates filter unary properties of tags.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{blocktag}} \sphinxhyphen{} The tag is on a block

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{filetag}} \sphinxhyphen{} The tag is on a file

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Binary Predicates}
\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index:binary-predicates}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
These predicates filter valued properties of tags.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{kind "string"}} \sphinxhyphen{} The kind of the tag. Only equality is supported. Ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{kind "ner"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{name "string"}} \sphinxhyphen{} The name of the tag. Only equality is supported. Ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{name "Dave"}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{file\_id "uuid string"}} \sphinxhyphen{} The UUID of the file to which the tag belongs.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{block\_id "uuid string"}} \sphinxhyphen{} The UUID of the block to which the tag belongs.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value("pathString") \textless{}op\textgreater{} \textless{}comparisonValue\textgreater{}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Comparison on the value (JSON content) of the tag.  Path string is a dot\sphinxhyphen{}separated key path in the json content.
Comparison value is a string, numeric, or boolean literal (lowercase).  Op can be:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{=}} \sphinxhyphen{} Equals. Ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value("approved") = true}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textgreater{}=}} \sphinxhyphen{} Greater than or equal to. Ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value("confidence") \textgreater{}= 0.5}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textgreater{}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Greater than.  Ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value("confidence") \textgreater{} 0.5}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textless{}=}} \sphinxhyphen{} Less than or equal to.  Ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value("confidence") \textless{}= 0.5}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textless{}}} \sphinxhyphen{} Less than.  Ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value("confidence") \textless{} 0.5}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{exists}} \sphinxhyphen{} Exists (no comparison value required).  Ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{value("active") exists}}

\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Binary Relations}
\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index:binary-relations}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Binary relations allow filtering on the relationship of a tag to another tag.
All relations require the 2nd matching tag to be distinct from the first.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Using them in the query language creates the context for a second tag, which may have additional predicates and relations.
Ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{kind "foo2" and overlaps \{ kind "bar2"\}}} means there exists a tag of kind “foo2” which overlaps a second tag of kind “bar2”.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{overlaps}} \sphinxhyphen{} The spans of the two tags overlap, and they are in the same block.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{samespan}} \sphinxhyphen{} The spans of the two tags match exactly, and they are in the same block.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sameblock}} \sphinxhyphen{} The two tags appear in the same block.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{samefile}} \sphinxhyphen{} The two tags appear in the same file.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Conjunctions}
\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index:conjunctions}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Conjunctions allow combinations of predicates and relations.
There is no order of operations between conjunctions;
groups of unlike conjunctions must be separated with parentheses,
ex: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{blocktag and (kind "foo3" or name "Tag6")}}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{and}}\sphinxhyphen{} Multiple predicates or relations can be intersected with and.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{or}} \sphinxhyphen{} Multiple predicates or relations may be disjoined with or.

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Special Predicates}
\label{\detokenize{data/queries/index:special-predicates}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{all}} \sphinxhyphen{} All may appear only at the top level of the query and must be the entire query.
It means to return all \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Files}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}}, or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tags}}.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstepscope


\section{Embedding Search Index}
\label{\detokenize{embedding-search/index:embedding-search-index}}\label{\detokenize{embedding-search/index:id1}}\label{\detokenize{embedding-search/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship provides a built\sphinxhyphen{}in vector store and search interface. This can be used in
combination with a {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/embedders/index:embedders}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Embedder}}}} to quickly create a search over text, images,
or other content. To use the index, first create an instance of it with your preferred \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Embedder}}
plugin (we recommend OpenAI):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{index} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{steamship}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{use\PYGZus{}plugin}\PYG{p}{(}
      \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{embedding\PYGZhy{}index}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
      \PYG{n}{random\PYGZus{}name}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}
      \PYG{n}{config}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{embedder}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}
          \PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
              \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{plugin\PYGZus{}handle}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{openai\PYGZhy{}embedder}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
              \PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{fetch\PYGZus{}if\PYGZus{}exists}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{k+kc}{True}
          \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
      \PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
  \PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Once you’ve created the index and paired it with the embedder, Steamship will automatically vectorize
content as it is inserted and queried.


\section{Inserting Data}
\label{\detokenize{embedding-search/index:inserting-data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The unit of insertion in a search index is :ref:\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tags}}.  Embedding search is most useful on short\sphinxhyphen{}ish chunks
of text like sentences or short paragraphs. If your text or content is in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Blocks}}, you can create \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Tags}}
over the spans that you wish to index and then insert them.


\section{Querying Data}
\label{\detokenize{embedding-search/index:querying-data}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Once you’ve inserted content, you can query it using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{query()}} method.

\sphinxstepscope


\section{Developing Packages and Plugins}
\label{\detokenize{developing/index:developing-packages-and-plugins}}\label{\detokenize{developing/index:developingpackagesandplugins}}\label{\detokenize{developing/index::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Think of Steamship packages and plugins as PyPi modules that run in the cloud.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{packages/index:packages}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Packages}}}} expose endpoints that can do work on an associated {\hyperref[\detokenize{data/workspaces:workspaces}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{workspace}}}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/index:plugins}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Plugins}}}} conform to interfaces defined by the Steamship Engine to perform common tasks.

\end{itemize}

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{warning}{Warning:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Third\sphinxhyphen{}party plugin development is currently in Alpha and the interface may change.
If you want to build a plugin, we are eager to chat!
Just email \sphinxhref{mailto:hello@steamship.com}{hello@steamship.com} or hop on our \sphinxhref{http://steamship.com/discord}{Discord}
\end{sphinxadmonition}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship is designed from the ground up to support building, modifying, and sharing both packages and plugins.
Each one you create is cloned from an existing template of your choosing.
That template contains everything you need for a great development lifecycle:
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{.}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A manifest file with metadata and statically\sphinxhyphen{}typed configuration

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Unit tests with pre\sphinxhyphen{}configured GitHub Actions integration

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Secrets management

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A pre\sphinxhyphen{}written main body to build from

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Simple deployment via the Steamship CLI and/or GitHub Actions

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The process for  details are located in the following pages:

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Cloning a Starter Package}
\label{\detokenize{developing/project-creation:cloning-a-starter-package}}\label{\detokenize{developing/project-creation::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
We have several packages available to start from:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://github.com/steamship-packages/empty-package}{Empty Package} \sphinxhyphen{} Bare\sphinxhyphen{}bones starter package shell

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://github.com/steamship-packages/prompt-api-template}{Prompt API template} \sphinxhyphen{} Turn a GPT prompt into an API

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://github.com/steamship-packages/chat-analytics}{Chat analytics} \sphinxhyphen{} Cluster chatroom messages into conversations and classify intent and sentiment

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://github.com/steamship-packages/ticket-tagging-api}{Ticket Tagging} \sphinxhyphen{} Tag service tickets with a zero\sphinxhyphen{}shot classifier, then transition to a trained model

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxhref{https://github.com/steamship-packages/audio-markdown}{Audio to Markdown} \sphinxhyphen{} Create a markdown file from an audio transcript, using specific command words

\end{itemize}

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Steamship Manifest Files}
\label{\detokenize{developing/steamship-manifest:steamship-manifest-files}}\label{\detokenize{developing/steamship-manifest:id1}}\label{\detokenize{developing/steamship-manifest::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Every Steamship package and plugin has a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} file at its
root that describes the project to Steamship.

\sphinxAtStartPar
At a minimum, when you create a new project, you should fill out the following fields:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{handle}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{description}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{version}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{public}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Plugin and package handles are globally unique across Steamship.
They are how other code will refer to your project when using it.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The full list of fields is:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{type}} \sphinxhyphen{} Either \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{package}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{plugin}}. Tells Steamship how to
interpret this project. A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{package}} is a user library that
others import and use. It can define custom endpoints and do anything
from process audio files to implement a calculator. A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{plugin}} is
an extension to the Steamship Engine. Plugins follow a strict
interface contract governed by their plugin type.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{handle}} \sphinxhyphen{} A globally unique identifier for the package, consisting
of lowercase letters, numbers, and dashes. This is the name by which
you will refer to your package elsewhere in Steamship code.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{version}} \sphinxhyphen{} The version of your project, in SemVer style (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{X.Y.Z}}
or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{X.Y.Z\sphinxhyphen{}abc123}}). By default, the last version you deploy is the
default used when new instances are created, but users can always
specify an older version.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{public}} \sphinxhyphen{} Whether users other than you can see and use this
project.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{author}} \sphinxhyphen{} Your name and contact information.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{description}} \sphinxhyphen{} A short, one sentence description of the project’s
purpose.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{plugin}} \sphinxhyphen{} Plugin\sphinxhyphen{}specific configuration. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{developing/steamship-manifest:plugin-manifest-config}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{description here}}}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{configTemplate}} \sphinxhyphen{} A schema for the configuration your project requires . See \DUrole{xref,std,std-ref}{the configuration documentation} for details.

\end{itemize}


\subsubsection{Plugin Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{developing/steamship-manifest:plugin-configuration}}\label{\detokenize{developing/steamship-manifest:plugin-manifest-config}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If your project is a Plugin, its \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} file contains a
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{plugin}} variable that defines further parameterization that is
specific to Plugins.

\sphinxAtStartPar
That configuration looks like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}plugin\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}type\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}tagger\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}isTrainable\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{false}
\PYG{+w}{  }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
That code shows the following required settings:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{type}} \sphinxhyphen{} Either \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fileImporter}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{corpusImporter}},
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{blockifier}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{tagger}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{embedder}}, or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{exporter}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{isTrainable}} \sphinxhyphen{} Whether the plugin can be trained.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A trainable plugin obligates it to implement a few extra methods as a
part of its contract with the Steamship Engine.


\subsubsection{Steamship Registry}
\label{\detokenize{developing/steamship-manifest:steamship-registry}}\label{\detokenize{developing/steamship-manifest:steamshipoutline}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship generates a \DUrole{xref,std,std-ref}{public web listing} for each public package and plugin.
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamshipRegistry}} block in your \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} file contains a fields which enhance this web listing:

\sphinxAtStartPar
That configuration looks like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}steamshipRegistry\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}imageUrl\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Url of an image icon for your project\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}tagline\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}One short sentence that describes your project.\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}tagline2\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}One short sentence that elaborates on the tagline.\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}usefulFor\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Useful for \PYGZlt{}insert your info here\PYGZgt{}.\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}videoUrl\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{null}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}githubUrl\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{null}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}demoUrl\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{null}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}blogUrl\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{null}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}jupyterUrl\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{null}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}authorName\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Name for Display on Steamship\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}authorImageUrl\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Direct URL for author image\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}authorGithub\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}GitHub Account used for author image as backup\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}authorEmail\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{null}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}authorTwitter\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{null}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}authorUrl\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k+kc}{null}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{n+nt}{\PYGZdq{}tags\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{[}
\PYG{+w}{        }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Tag1\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{+w}{        }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}Tag2\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{+w}{      }\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{+w}{    }\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
All these fields are optional. When non\sphinxhyphen{}empty, your project’s web listing will gain additional UI features.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Environment Setup}
\label{\detokenize{developing/environment-setup:environment-setup}}\label{\detokenize{developing/environment-setup::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship plugins are written in Python.
We’ve standardized on \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{venv}} for dependency management,
and every plugin starter template comes with a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{requirements.txt}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{requirements.dev.txt}} file describing
its dependencies.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you add new dependencies as you develop, it is important that you add them to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{requirements.txt}}.
Otherwise they will not be available when you deploy your plugin to the cloud.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To set up your virtual environment for the first time, run this command from your plugin’s root directory:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
python3\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}m\PYG{+w}{ }venv\PYG{+w}{ }.venv
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
You can activate your virtual environment by running:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nb}{source}\PYG{+w}{ }.venv/bin/activate
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Your first time, or any time you add a dependency, run:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
python\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}m\PYG{+w}{ }pip\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}r\PYG{+w}{ }requirements.dev.txt
python\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}m\PYG{+w}{ }pip\PYG{+w}{ }install\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}r\PYG{+w}{ }requirements.txt
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Accepting Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{developing/configuration:accepting-configuration}}\label{\detokenize{developing/configuration::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Your package or plugin may need to accept configuration to be usable.
Examples might include:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
An API key to invoke a third\sphinxhyphen{}party service

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A parameter setting, such as a threshold or output class

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A configuration parameter has:
\sphinxhyphen{}  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{type}} \sphinxhyphen{} Either \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{boolean}}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{string}}, or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{number}}.
\sphinxhyphen{}  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{description}} \sphinxhyphen{} A short description of the parameter.
\sphinxhyphen{}  \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{default}} \sphinxhyphen{} A default value if the user does not provide one.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If a parameter does not have a default value, and a Steamship user tries
to create a new instance without specifying it, that instance creation
will fail. Similarly, provided values with incorrect types will be rejected. This
means that your package or plugin is guaranteed to receive a config that structurally matches.

\begin{sphinxadmonition}{note}{Note:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
There is currently no such thing as an optional configuration parameter. All parameters that do
not have a default value must have a value provided by the user at Package instantiation.
\end{sphinxadmonition}


\subsubsection{Defining and Accepting configuration in your code}
\label{\detokenize{developing/configuration:defining-and-accepting-configuration-in-your-code}}\label{\detokenize{developing/configuration:id1}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To define the configuration for your Package, create a class that inherits from Config:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{MyPackageConfig}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{Config}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
     \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}string\PYGZus{}config\PYGZus{}param}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n+nb}{str} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Field}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{my\PYGZhy{}default\PYGZhy{}value}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
                                 \PYG{n}{description}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{A param this package needs which is a string.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
     \PYG{n}{my\PYGZus{}numeric\PYGZus{}config\PYGZus{}param}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n+nb}{float} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{Field}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{description}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{A numeric param this package needs.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
and then return this class from your package or plugin’s \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{config\_cls}} class method:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{class} \PYG{n+nc}{MyPackageClass}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{PackageService}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{n}{config}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{MyPackageConfig}

    \PYG{n+nd}{@classmethod}
    \PYG{k}{def} \PYG{n+nf}{config\PYGZus{}cls}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb+bp}{cls}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}} \PYG{n}{Type}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{Config}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{:}
         \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{MyPackageConfig}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will guarantee that \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_string\_config\_param}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_numeric\_config\_param}} are set for all invocations
of your package or plugin.  Since \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_strong\_config\_param}} provides a default value, the user can omit it
from their configuration and the value \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{"my\sphinxhyphen{}default\sphinxhyphen{}value"}} will be used.  Since \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{my\_numeric\_config\_param}}
does not have a default value, a user \sphinxstyleemphasis{must} supply a value to create an instance of your package or plugin.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To use the config values within your code, you can then refer to them from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{self.config}},
as in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{self.config.my\_numeric\_config\_param}}.  They will be automatically populated with the user’s
data by Steamship when invoking your package or plugin.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Storing Secrets}
\label{\detokenize{developing/storing-secrets:storing-secrets}}\label{\detokenize{developing/storing-secrets::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You may wish your plugin instance to store secrets, such as an API key or random seed.
These should never be committed to your plugin’s GitHub repository, but they can be easily bundled and loaded automatically during deployment.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Simply place your secrets in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{src/.steamship/secrets.toml}} and ensure that they are git\sphinxhyphen{}ignored.
All default plugin templates should have this file already git\sphinxhyphen{}ignored.
For example, your \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{secrets.toml}} file might look like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{api\PYGZus{}key}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s}{\PYGZdq{}be\PYGZsh{}45jdkjdsdfse3\PYGZdq{}}
\PYG{n}{random\PYGZus{}seed}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+m+mi}{12345}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship’s plugin loader will automatically detect this file and attempt to set any properties on your plugin’s
configuration object that have matching keys.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Note:} Automated deployments via GitHub\sphinxhyphen{}actions will not have this git\sphinxhyphen{}ignored file.
To automate deployments that contain secrets, you will need to alter your GitHub Action scripts to create
these files using GitHub Secrets after the checkout but before the deployment.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Running on Localhost}
\label{\detokenize{developing/running:running-on-localhost}}\label{\detokenize{developing/running::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To run your project on localhost type:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
ship\PYG{+w}{ }run\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nb}{local}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
This will start a local instance with a number of ways to interact with it:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Console REPL, which will start immediately in the console.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
An HTTP endpoint, which will be printed to the console

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
A Web endpoint, which will be printed to the console

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The output will look like this:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Running\PYG{+w}{ }your\PYG{+w}{ }project..

🌎\PYG{+w}{ }Public\PYG{+w}{ }API:\PYG{+w}{ }https://example.ngrok.org/...
🌎\PYG{+w}{ }Local\PYG{+w}{ }API:\PYG{+w}{  }http://localhost:8080/...
🌎\PYG{+w}{ }Web\PYG{+w}{ }URL:\PYG{+w}{    }https://steamship:com/debug?https://...

💬\PYG{+w}{ }Interactive\PYG{+w}{ }REPL\PYG{+w}{ }below.

You:\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZus{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Localhost caveats}
\label{\detokenize{developing/running:localhost-caveats}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Running on localhost currently does not yet support asynchronous tasks.
In practice, this most often comes up with our \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DocumentIndexerPipelineMixin}}, which enables loading in PDFs, YouTube videos, and other large documents for vector storage and retrieval.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Throw, Log, and Test!}
\label{\detokenize{developing/testing:throw-log-and-test}}\label{\detokenize{developing/testing:testing}}\label{\detokenize{developing/testing::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship plugins execute remotely, automatically, and potentially at high\sphinxhyphen{}scale.
This makes it critical that you:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Throw detailed exceptions eagerly

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Log liberally

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Write unit tests

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Every plugin template comes with a detailed logging and testing setup.


\subsubsection{Logging}
\label{\detokenize{developing/testing:logging}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
We recommend that you log liberally within your plugin code.
Use Python’s default \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{logging}} library.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{logging}
\PYG{n}{logging}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{info}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Hi there!}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Throwing Errors}
\label{\detokenize{developing/testing:throwing-errors}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
When something goes wrong in a plugin, the correct response is to throw a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SteamshipError}}.
This will result in an error message returned to the end\sphinxhyphen{}user.

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{from} \PYG{n+nn}{steamship} \PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n}{SteamshipError}
\PYG{k}{raise} \PYG{n}{SteamshipError}\PYG{p}{(}
   \PYG{n}{message}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Some error message}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{error}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{optional\PYGZus{}wrapped\PYGZus{}error}
\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsubsection{Manual Testing}
\label{\detokenize{developing/testing:manual-testing}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Your plugin template comes with a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{test/}} folder that stores \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pytest}} tests. You can run them with:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
pytest
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Many templates additionally contain a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{test\_data/}} folder with data that is read in as part of testing.

\sphinxAtStartPar
On your local machine, any tests will run using the run using the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_API\_KEY}} environment variable, if available, or using the key specified in your user\sphinxhyphen{}global Steamship settings (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{\textasciitilde{}/.steamship.json}}).


\subsubsection{Automated testing}
\label{\detokenize{developing/testing:automated-testing}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Your plugin template comes configured to auto\sphinxhyphen{}test upon pull\sphinxhyphen{}requests to the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{main}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{staging}} branches.
Testing will also be performed as part of the {\hyperref[\detokenize{developing/deploying:deploying}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{automated deployment}}}}.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Failing tests are will block any automated deployments

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
We recommend configuring your repository to block pull\sphinxhyphen{}request merges unless a passing test has been registered

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Automated testing setup}
\label{\detokenize{developing/testing:automated-testing-setup}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Testing requires that you set a GitHub secret named \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship\_key\_test}}. This secret will be used to set the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_API\_KEY}} environment variable during test running.


\paragraph{Modifying or removing automated testing}
\label{\detokenize{developing/testing:modifying-or-removing-automated-testing}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Automated tests are run from the GitHub workflow located in your plugin project at \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.github/workflows/test.yml}}

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Deploying}
\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:deploying}}\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:id1}}\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Packages and plugins must be deployed before they can be used.

\sphinxAtStartPar
New versions of your project automatically become the “default” version when new instances are created.
Unless an instance specifically requests a version, this new default version will be used.


\subsubsection{Deploying with the Steamship CLI}
\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:deploying-with-the-steamship-cli}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
You can deploy a package or plugin with the Steamship CLI with single command from
the project root (make sure your python environment is active):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
ship\PYG{+w}{ }deploy
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
If you don’t have a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} yet, the deploy process will create one. After the command exits, wait a few minutes for your new infrastructure to be ready in the cloud.
New instances of your project will then be directed to the new version.


\subsubsection{Deploying via GitHub Actions}
\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:deploying-via-github-actions}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Each package and plugin project is created from a a template that has been pre\sphinxhyphen{}configured to
auto\sphinxhyphen{}deploy within GitHub Actions when certain situations occur.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Before you deploy, make sure the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{handle}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{version}} fields in your \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} file are set:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{handle}} property of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{version}} property of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Production deployments occur upon:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Pushes to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{main}}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Pushes to SemVer\sphinxhyphen{}style tags, prefixed with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{v}} (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{vA.B.C}})

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Staging deployments occur upon:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Pushes to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{staging}}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
When pushing to a SemVer\sphinxhyphen{}style tag, the tag’s version must match the
version contained within \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}}. Note that while the GitHub
branch must start with \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{v}}, the version identifier in
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} should omit it.

\sphinxAtStartPar
When pushing to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{main}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{staging}}, the version contained in
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} is used.


\paragraph{Automated Deployment Setup}
\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:automated-deployment-setup}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Automated deployments can only occur if you have set the following
GitHub secrets:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_KEY}} GitHub repository secret

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_API\_BASE}} GitHub repository secret (optional)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_KEY\_STAGING}} GitHub repository secret

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_API\_BASE\_STAGING}} GitHub repository secret
(optional)

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Setting the following variable will additionally trigger Slack
notifications upon automated deployments:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_SLACK\_DEPLOYMENT\_WEBHOOK}} Slack notification webhook
URL (optional)

\end{itemize}


\paragraph{Modifying or disabling automated deployments}
\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:modifying-or-disabling-automated-deployments}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Automated deployment is triggered by the GitHub Actions workflow in
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.github/workflows/deploy.yml}}. This file, in turn, invokes the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship\sphinxhyphen{}core/deploy\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}steamship@main}} action.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To modify or disable automated deployments, remove, comment out, or
modify that file.


\subsubsection{Troubleshooting Deployments}
\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:troubleshooting-deployments}}

\paragraph{The deployment fails because the version already exists}
\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:the-deployment-fails-because-the-version-already-exists}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This means the version specified in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} has already been
registered with Steamship. Simply update the version in
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} to an identifier that has not yet been used.


\paragraph{The deployment fails because the tag does not match the manifest file}
\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:the-deployment-fails-because-the-tag-does-not-match-the-manifest-file}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This means you have tried to push a branch with a semver\sphinxhyphen{}style tag (like
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{v1.2.3}}), resulting in a version deployment whose name must match
that tag without the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{v}} prefix (\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1.2.3}}). Make sure the version
field of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} matches this string.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For example, if you are deploying branch \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{v6.0.0}}, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{version}}
field of your \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.json}} file must be \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{6.0.0}}


\paragraph{The deployment fails with an authentication error}
\label{\detokenize{developing/deploying:the-deployment-fails-with-an-authentication-error}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If you’re deploying from GitHub Actions, make sure you’re set your
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEAMSHIP\_KEY}} in your GitHub secrets. If you’re deploying from your
local machine, make sure you’ve authenticated with the Steamship CLI.

\sphinxstepscope


\subsection{Monitoring}
\label{\detokenize{developing/monitoring:monitoring}}\label{\detokenize{developing/monitoring:id1}}\label{\detokenize{developing/monitoring::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship enables easy monitoring of the health and behavior of your running
{\hyperref[\detokenize{packages/index:packages}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Packages}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/index:plugins}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Plugins}}}}.


\subsubsection{Monitoring via Web}
\label{\detokenize{developing/monitoring:monitoring-via-web}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Steamship’s website provides a hub for monitoring your packages and plugins. The monitoring page for
an instance provides application logs, a detailed breakdown of usage, and a view of related
{\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/using/tasks:tasks}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Tasks}}}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
To access the monitoring page for an instance, visit the instance page. For example, for a package instance,
you will need both the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{workspace\_handle}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{package\_instance\_handle}} for your instance to find the URL.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Visit: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{https://www.steamship.com/workspaces/\{workspace\_handle\}/packages/\{package\_instance\_handle\}/monitor}} to
access the Steamship monitoring.


\paragraph{Logs}
\label{\detokenize{developing/monitoring:logs}}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{logs-example}.png}


\paragraph{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{developing/monitoring:usage}}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{usage-example}.png}


\paragraph{Tasks}
\label{\detokenize{developing/monitoring:tasks}}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{tasks-example}.png}


\subsubsection{Using Logging in Instances}
\label{\detokenize{developing/monitoring:using-logging-in-instances}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Our logging integration helps monitor the behavior of deployed instances, providing detailed
information about critical state in your deployments. You may add your own custom logging statements to
your {\hyperref[\detokenize{packages/index:packages}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Packages}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{plugins/index:plugins}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Plugins}}}} to help in your development of new features, or to troubleshoot behavior in
existing instances.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Add custom logs using the Python \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{logging}} library:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{logging}
\PYG{n}{logging}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{info}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{running agent with prompt: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{prompt}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
It is also possible to add extra structured fields to your generated log entries to help in filtered retrieval later:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import} \PYG{n+nn}{logging}
\PYG{n}{logging}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{info}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{running agent with prompt: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{prompt}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{,}
             \PYG{n}{extra}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{request\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{request\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{user}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{user}\PYG{p}{\PYGZcb{}}
\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
When a deployed instance is running, all logs at the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{INFO}} level and above will be generated, processed by Steamship,
and made available for retrieval within a few minutes.


\subsubsection{Logs Retrieval with \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{ship}} CLI}
\label{\detokenize{developing/monitoring:logs-retrieval-with-ship-cli}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
To look up logs via the Steamship CLI, use the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ship logs}} command. It will return a JSON object that contains
the relevant log entries.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Here is an example command to retrieve logs with extra fields in the example workspace \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship\sphinxhyphen{}example\sphinxhyphen{}logs\sphinxhyphen{}001}}:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
ship\PYG{+w}{ }logs\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}w\PYG{+w}{ }steamship\PYGZhy{}example\PYGZhy{}logs\PYGZhy{}001\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}f\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}request\PYGZus{}id=99999999\PYGZdq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Because \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ship logs}} returns JSON, you can use \sphinxhref{https://jqlang.github.io/jq/}{jq} to help trim the output to meet your needs:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
ship\PYG{+w}{ }logs\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}w\PYG{+w}{ }steamship\PYGZhy{}example\PYGZhy{}logs\PYGZhy{}001\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}f\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}request\PYGZus{}id=99999999\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{p}{|}\PYG{+w}{ }jq\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}.entries[].message\PYGZsq{}}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For full information on how to use \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ship logs}}, run:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
ship\PYG{+w}{ }logs\PYG{+w}{ }\PYGZhy{}\PYGZhy{}help
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxstepscope

An instance of a configured prompt completion service such as GPT\sphinxhyphen{}3.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxtitleref{generate} method synchronously invokes the prompt against a set of variables that parameterize it.
The return value is a single string.
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Example Usage:}
\sphinxAtStartPar
llm = Steamship.use(‘prompt\sphinxhyphen{}generation\sphinxhyphen{}default’, config=\{ “temperature”: 0.9 \})
PROMPT = “Greet \{name\} as if he were a \{relation\}.”
greeting = llm.generate(PROMPT, \{“name”: “Ted”, “relation”: “old friend”\})

\end{description}

\subparagraph{steamship.invocable.entrypoint module}
\label{\detokenize{api/steamship.invocable:module-steamship.invocable.entrypoint}}\label{\detokenize{api/steamship.invocable:steamship-invocable-entrypoint-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!steamship.invocable.entrypoint@\spxentry{steamship.invocable.entrypoint}}\index{steamship.invocable.entrypoint@\spxentry{steamship.invocable.entrypoint}!module@\spxentry{module}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
This class is necessary to be able to please the entrypoints of both localstack and AWS.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If we set the entrypoint directly to steamship.invocable.safe\_handler (imported in the init
from lambda\_handler), AWS is happy, but localstack is not because it tries to read steamship.invocable as a py file,
not a module.

\sphinxAtStartPar
If we set the entrypoint to steamship.invocable.lambda\_handler.safe\_handler, Localstack is happy, but AWS
is not, because it tries to read lambda\_handler first, which imports things from steamship.invocable, which imports
things from lambda\_handler.

\sphinxAtStartPar
By adding this file which basically no\sphinxhyphen{}ops safe\_handler into steamship.invocable.entrypoint.safe\_handler, both are
happy.

\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{post\_update}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{client}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.base:steamship.base.client.Client}]{\sphinxcrossref{Client}}}}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Pushes this response object to the corresponding Task on the Steamship Engine.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Typically apps and plugins return their results to the Engine synchronously via HTTP.
But sometimes that’s not practice \textendash{} for example:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Microsoft’s OCR endpoint returns a Job Token that can be exchanged for updates, and eventually a result.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Google’s AutoML can take 20\sphinxhyphen{}30 minutes to train.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fine\sphinxhyphen{}tuning BERT on ECS can take an arbitrarily long amount of time.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In these cases, it can be useful for the package/plugin to occasionally post updates to the Engine outside
of the Engine’s initial synchronous request\sphinxhyphen{}response conversation.

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The Abstract Base Class of a Steamship Plugin.

\sphinxAtStartPar
All Steamship Plugins implement the operation:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
run(PluginRequest{[}T{]}) \sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} Response{[}U{]}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Many plugins are effectively stateless. This run operation defines their entire capability.
Examples of such stateless plugins are:
\sphinxhyphen{} File Import Plugin
\sphinxhyphen{} Export Plugin

\sphinxAtStartPar
Other plugins have state but in a very controlled way:
\sphinxhyphen{} they can be trained,
\sphinxhyphen{} this trainable process produces a “model”,
\sphinxhyphen{} that model acts as the state on which the \sphinxtitleref{run} method is conditioned

\sphinxAtStartPar
This model is stored in the Steamship Workspace that owns the Plugin Instance, and access to it is provided by the
hosting environment that runs the model.
\sphinxhyphen{} TODO(ted) Document this process.

\sphinxAtStartPar
These stateful plugins are called “Trainable Plugins,” and they must implement the following additional methods:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
get\_training\_parameters(PluginRequest{[}TrainingParameterInput{]}) \sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} Response{[}TrainingParameterOutput{]}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
train(PluginRequest{[}TrainPluginInput{]}) \sphinxhyphen{}\textgreater{} Response{[}TrainPluginOutput{]}

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Produces the trainable parameters for this plugin.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This method is run by the Steamship Engine prior to training to fetch hyperparameters.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The user themselves can provide hyperparameters on the TrainingParameterPluginInput object.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
This method then transforms those into the TrainingParameterPluginOutput object, altering the user’s values
if desired.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The Engine then takes those TrainingParameterPluginOutput and presents them on the TrainPluginInput

\end{itemize}

\end{fulllineitems}

\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{post\_update}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n,n}{client}\DUrole{p,p}{:}\DUrole{w,w}{  }\DUrole{n,n}{{\hyperref[\detokenize{api/steamship.base:steamship.base.client.Client}]{\sphinxcrossref{Client}}}}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Pushes this response object to the corresponding Task on the Steamship Engine.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Typically apps and plugins return their results to the Engine synchronously via HTTP.
But sometimes that’s not practice \textendash{} for example:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Microsoft’s OCR endpoint returns a Job Token that can be exchanged for updates, and eventually a result.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Google’s AutoML can take 20\sphinxhyphen{}30 minutes to train.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fine\sphinxhyphen{}tuning BERT on ECS can take an arbitrarily long amount of time.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In these cases, it can be useful for the package/plugin to occasionally post updates to the Engine outside
of the Engine’s initial synchronous request\sphinxhyphen{}response conversation.

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Input for a plugin that accepts raw data, plus a mime type.

\sphinxAtStartPar
A plugin author need only ever concern themselves with two fields:
\sphinxhyphen{} \sphinxtitleref{data} \sphinxhyphen{} Raw bytes
\textasciigrave{} \sphinxtitleref{default\_mime\_type} \sphinxhyphen{} The best guess as to \sphinxtitleref{data}’s MIME Type unless otherwise known to be different.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In practice, however, the lifecycle of this object involves a bit more under the hood:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Potentially Base64 Decoding Data}. When decoding from a dict, the \sphinxtitleref{data} field is assumed to be Base64 encoded.
This is to support JSON as a transport encoding over the wire. The constructor automatically performs the
decoding, and the Steamship Engine automatically performs the encoding, so the Plugin Author can mostly ignore
this fact.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Potentially late\sphinxhyphen{}fetching the \textasciigrave{}data\textasciigrave{} from a \textasciigrave{}url\textasciigrave{}}. Some files are too large to comfortably send as Base64
within JSON. The Steamship Engine sometimes chooses to send an empty \sphinxtitleref{data} field paired with a non\sphinxhyphen{}empty
\sphinxtitleref{url} field. When this happens, the constructor proactively, synchronously fetches the contents of that \sphinxtitleref{url}
and assigns it to the \sphinxtitleref{data} field, throwing a SteamshipError if the fetch fails. Again, this is done
automatically so the Plugin Author can mostly ignore this fact.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Represents mime\sphinxhyphen{}typed raw data (or a URL pointing to raw data) that can be returned to the engine.

\sphinxAtStartPar
As a few examples, you can return:
\sphinxhyphen{} Raw text: RawDataPluginOutput(string=raw\_text, MimeTypes.TXT)
\sphinxhyphen{} Markdown text: RawDataPluginOutput(string=markdown\_text, MimeTypes.MKD)
\sphinxhyphen{} A PNG image: RawDataPluginOutput(bytes=png\_bytes, MimeTypes.PNG)
\sphinxhyphen{} A JSON\sphinxhyphen{}serializable Dataclass: RawDataPluginOutput(json=dataclass, MimeTypes.JSON)
\sphinxhyphen{} Steamship Blocks: RawDataPluginOutput(json=file, MimeTypes.STEAMSHIP\_BLOCK\_JSON)
\sphinxhyphen{} Data uploaded to a pre\sphinxhyphen{}signed URL: RawDataPluginOutput(url=presigned\_url, MimeTypes.TXT)

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxtitleref{data} field of this object will ALWAYS be Base64 encoded by the constructor. This ensures that the object
is always trivially JSON\sphinxhyphen{}serializable over the wire, no matter what it contains.

\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxtitleref{mimeType} field of this object should always be filled in if known. The Steamship Engine makes use of it
to proactively select defaults for handling the data returned.

\subparagraph{steamship.plugin.trainable\_model module}
\label{\detokenize{api/steamship.plugin:module-steamship.plugin.trainable_model}}\label{\detokenize{api/steamship.plugin:steamship-plugin-trainable-model-module}}\index{module@\spxentry{module}!steamship.plugin.trainable\_model@\spxentry{steamship.plugin.trainable\_model}}\index{steamship.plugin.trainable\_model@\spxentry{steamship.plugin.trainable\_model}!module@\spxentry{module}}\index{TrainableModel (class in steamship.plugin.trainable\_model)@\spxentry{TrainableModel}\spxextra{class in steamship.plugin.trainable\_model}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{api/steamship.plugin:steamship.plugin.trainable_model.TrainableModel}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class\DUrole{w,w}{  }}}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{steamship.plugin.trainable\_model.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{TrainableModel}}}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Bases: \sphinxhref{https://docs.python.org/3.11/library/abc.html\#abc.ABC}{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ABC}}}, \sphinxhref{https://docs.python.org/3.11/library/typing.html\#typing.Generic}{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Generic}}}{[}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ConfigType}}{]}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Base class for trainable models.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Trainable models are not plugins. They are a thin wrapper around the state of a model designed to be \sphinxstylestrong{used with}
the Steamship plugin system.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\# State Management

\sphinxAtStartPar
100\% of a TrainableModel’s state management should save to \& read from a folder on disk via the methods
\sphinxtitleref{save\_to\_folder} and \sphinxtitleref{load\_from\_folder}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\# Remote Saving and Loading

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxtitleref{TrainableModel} instances automatically save to a user’s Workspace on Steamship via \sphinxtitleref{save\_remote} method. They
can load themselves from a user’s workspace via the \sphinxtitleref{load\_remote} method.

\sphinxAtStartPar
When saving a model, the caller provides \sphinxtitleref{handle}, such as “V1” or “epoch\_23”. This allows that particular checkpoint
to be re\sphinxhyphen{}loaded. By default, every save operation also saves the model to the “default” checkpoint, overwriting it
if it already existed. When a user loads a model without specifying a checkpoint, the “default” checkpoint will be used.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\# Data Scope

\sphinxAtStartPar
A TrainableModel’s data is saved \& loaded with respect to
\begin{enumerate}
\sphinxsetlistlabels{\arabic}{enumi}{enumii}{}{)}%
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The user’s active Workspace, and

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The provided Plugin Instance within that workspace.

\end{enumerate}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The active workspace is read from the Steamship client context, and the \sphinxtitleref{plugin\_instance\_id} is supplied as a
method argument on the \sphinxtitleref{save\_remote} and \sphinxtitleref{load\_remote} methods.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This organization enables a user to have arbitrarily many trained model instances of the same type colocated within
a Workspace.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\# Training

\sphinxAtStartPar
A training job is fully parameterized by the \sphinxtitleref{TrainPluginInput} object.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\# Result Reporting

\sphinxAtStartPar
A training job’s results are reported via the \sphinxtitleref{TrainPluginOutput} object. These results include a reference to the
\sphinxtitleref{save\_remote} output, but they do not include the model parameters themselves. For example, after training, one
could write:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{archive\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}in\PYGZus{}steamship} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{model}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{save\PYGZus{}remote}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{g+gp}{\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{}\PYGZgt{} }\PYG{n}{output} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{TrainPluginOutput}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{archive\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}in\PYGZus{}steamship}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{archive\PYGZus{}path\PYGZus{}in\PYGZus{}steamship}\PYG{p}{,}
\PYG{g+go}{    ...}
\PYG{g+go}{    )}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\sphinxAtStartPar
That output is the ultimate return object of the training process, but the Plugin that owns this model need not
wait for synchronous completion to update the Steamship Engine with intermediate results. It can use the
\sphinxtitleref{Response.post\_update} to proactively stream results back to the server.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\# Third\sphinxhyphen{}party / External Models

\sphinxAtStartPar
This model class is a convenient wrapper for models running on third party systems (e.g. Google’s AutoML). In such
a case:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxtitleref{train} method would begin the job on the 3rd party system.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxtitleref{save\_to\_folder} method would write the Job ID and any other useful data to the checkpoint path

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxtitleref{load\_from\_folder} method would read this Job ID from disk and obtain an authenticated client with the
third party system.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Any \sphinxtitleref{run} method the implementer created would ferry back results fetched from the third\sphinxhyphen{}party system.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Any status reporting in TrainPluginOutput would ferry back status fetched from the third\sphinxhyphen{}party system.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A simple key value store implemented in Steamship.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Instances of the KeyValueStore are identified by its  \sphinxtitleref{namespace}.
This store\_identifier corresponds to a File that will be created with a special tag identifying it.
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Entries of the KeyValueStore are saved as \sphinxtitleref{Tag} objects with:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Kind = “KeyValueStore”

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Name = the key of the (kv) pair

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Value = a dict set to the value

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note that the value is always saved as a dict object. To save a string or int, wrap it in a dict.

\sphinxAtStartPar
WARNING:

\sphinxAtStartPar
This is essentially a clever hack atop Steamship’s tag system to provide mutable key\sphinxhyphen{}value storage. It is in the
steamship.utils package because it’s proven useful once or twice. But in general, if you find yourself heavily
relying upon it, consider reaching out to us at \sphinxhref{mailto:hello@steamship.com}{hello@steamship.com} to let us know, and we’ll up\sphinxhyphen{}prioritize
adding a proper key\sphinxhyphen{}value API.
